div1.p: Blincoe provides recollections of Walter Reed, and includes a transcription of Thomas Reed's letter.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Reed Blincoe to Howard A. Kelly, February 9, 1903
div1.p:
Letters from my
brothers give very little more information
concerning Walter's early life than I
was already in possession of and I might
have written you a week ago about what
I shall now note down. My brother,
Thomes Walk Reed, who lives in Kansas
writes, and I may as well here give
you my reason for rewriting his letter
instead of sending it. By an unfortunate
accident, he lost his right-hand
when 41 years old and doesn't write
as plainly with his left-hand as he
used to do -- hence though I make him
out finely, I was afraid you might have
some trouble- He says “From the time
I entered the army in 1862 I was
only with Walter short periods of time.
When we lived in Charlottesville, I
was in business with Antrim & Son
& boarded with them the greater part
of the time- Walter always impressed
me with his manly ways far more
than most boys of his age. In 1866
when Pa first moved to Charlottesville,
he was put in a private school taught
C1
B3
by a Mr: Abbott who was an A.H.
of the University of Va. He limited himself
to 20 pupils- His was a special course
preparatory to the University, Walter
was with Prof. Abbott two sessions, I
think. He then entered the University
under age, but permitted to do so because
he had two brothers there. His intentions
were to take the degree of A.M. and
having made the standard in three or
four of his studies he was refused
his graduation papers because he
was under age, being required to stand
his examinations again after becoming
old enough. He was indignant- He was
at the time before the full faculty
pleading his own case -- a boy not
quite 16 years of age -- as you well
know. After being refused his graduation
papers by the faculty in the classes
he had made, he turned to the Med-
ical Board of the faculty and said to
them, “Gentlemen, I have changed my
mind in regard to what I had intended
to do -- take the degree of A.M- If I take
the Medical Course & make the
standard, will you give me my
diploma as an M.D.?” They all
nodded their heads with a smile
not thinking for a moment that he
would perform such a task. He then
turned to Dr. Maupin, Chairman of
the faculty, and said, “Dr, you have
heard what these gentlemen say.
Will you see that I have my degree
of M. D. if I make the standard?”
Dr: Maupin replied that he would.
Walter then said, “Gentlemen, I hold
you to your solemn pledge” & bowing
to them, went out. I cannot remember
now who it was that was present &
related the incident to me but whoever
it was, said that he was very digni-
fied & made quite an impression.
Walter at once applied himself to
the task and graduated the next
summer, third, in his class.

Dr: Maupin on presenting his
diploma said the he was the youngest
man ever graduated from the school
but they were in honor bound to
deliver him his diploma. There are
two other incidents of his childhood
that occur to me but they are hardly
worth relating. When he was about six
years old he was sent for the first time
to a school in Farmville- Taught by Mr
George E. Broker. Pa had asked Mr: Broker
C1
B3
to be very lenient with him and allow
him to play out of doors as much as he
thought he could do. He had two signs
at the door- with “out” on one side and
“In” on the other- Only two could be absent
at once but Walter was not required to
turn the sign- He could go out without
permission & soon he staid out all
the time. Mr: Broker sent for him one
day & had him brought in. As the little
fellow marched to his seat Mr. Broker
said, Walter, you are like the little
boy that went to see his grandmother,
aren't you, as Walter tried to explain
that he had been out only twice that
day- We were all curious to hear how
the comparison would be- Mr: Broker
soon told us that the little boy went
only twice a year to see his grandmother
and staid six months each time!
Of course the whole school had a hearty
laugh at his expense & he seemed to
enjoy it as much as we did. The other
incident was when Pa was recommend
ing the merits of the old fashioned Va
corn bread one day at a meal. He said
if we would eat it that it would help
us to grow fast & make us strong
men. We were not impressed with
2
his recommendation but he insisted
upon helping each one with a small
piece for encouragement. As he handed
the piece to Walter it slipped & fell in
the waiter with the cups & saucers. He
said! There, my son, is your piece in
Mother's waiter! Walter replied, “Yes,
sir, let it stay there” and it stayed!
Our father, full of humour, enjoyed
the joke on himself, hugely.

When I lost my hand the 28th
day of Sep- 1883, my thoughts turned
to Walter almost immediately- I
begged Kit (our brother Christopher)
to wire for him- He was stationed
at Omaha, Nebraska, at the time
& was packed up & on the eve of
a move. Yet he came to me at once
arriving one Sunday morning. Opening
the door of my room & throwing his
cloak from his shoulders, he knelt
by my bedside & kissed me time
& again. He handled my poor arm
as tenderly as a woman could have
done & for the four days he spent
with me, did all that was possible
to be done. I was suffering horribly
when he came & threatened, I feared,
with blood poisoning. He took out
C1
B3
all the stitches that had been put
in & treated it as an open wound.
with such success that it healed
quite rapidly. I was grievouly dis-
appointed when last in Virginia
that I did not see Walter. I had
fully intended to go to Washington
but circumstances over which I had
no control, prevented.” L. W. Reed-

This is all that refers
in any way to Walter in my brother's
letter -- but speaking of Farmville
reminded me of a small incident
in which Walter was concerned- Farm-
ville is a great place for the tobacco
trade- Farmers bring in their loose
weed & it is sold & stored in large
warehouses- One afternoon in company
with other small boys, (& larger ones
too, I suspect), Walter went the rounds
of the warehouses- As the boys sampled
or tasted the tobacco, he did so too &
was made very sick- The boys saw
him ill & hurried to carry him
home -- frightened out of their wits
too, to think of the dire punishment
ahead of them when their seniors
should find out what they had
been doing- On their way home they
begged, “Walter if it kills you, don't
tell on us,” & the poor little fellow
promised, if it killed him he would
not tell! Another incident of his
child life which showed his tender,
affectionate nature occurred about 2
years afterwards- I had had quite
a spell of illness at my parents'
home in Bedford City- He came
up to my room one morning to see
me & to inquire how I was- When
I said, “I think that I'm really
a little better this morning, my darling”
he replied, with beaming face, “I had
rather heard that sound from your
lips than to have had a check for
$500.00 put in my hands this morning”
I have often thought that was quite
an appreciative speech from a boy of
his age- Just here occurs another
small incident that I have often
smiled over in thinking of him. My
mother told me about it sometime
after it occurred. When he was about
six years old she was about to
punish him for something & as she ap-
proached him, switch in hand, he
fell at her feet & with small arms
C1
B3
clasped around her knees, he looked
up with a most beseeching expression
on his face & exclaimed, “O, my
beautiful mother, how can you
punish your dear little boy”?
He won the day!

He joined the Methodist Church
in Charlottesville in Feb: 1866-
when a little over fourteen years
old - but was only a resident of
Charlottesville until after his
graduation. Inasmuch as his various
duties called him from place to place, I do not
think he kept up his connection
with the visible Church. He was
brought up “in the nurture and
admonition of the Lord” -- lovingly,
tenderly, but firmly rooted & grounded
in the principles of our holy Christianity-
I cannot remember an act of his life
inconsistent with the highest principles
of morality. The fruits of the Spirit,
Love, Joy, Peace -- Long suffering -- goodness
gentleness, charity were exhibited in his
daily life. As I think I mentioned
in my former letter, I was twelve years
his senior & the only sister for twenty
seven years, (another sister then being
born by my father's second marriage)
3
and I can honestly say that from
the day of his birth- through his baby,
hood, boyhood & manhood, his
life was one of sweetness & love.

Often in thinking of him I have
been impressed with his wonderfully
interesting personality. Never ostenta-
tious, never seeming to realize that he
was doing anything uncommon, he was
always up to the standard in whatever
he undertook. He was the possessor
of a good strong constitution -- rarely
ever sick, except with the usual chil-
dren's diseases -- was always in a
good humour -- cheerful & bright,
ready for work or play as occasion
called forth. He was fond of horses,
dogs & all other domestic animals &
lived for the greater part of his boyhood
in the country when he was familiar
with all such- He had a pet of his
own -- a beautiful brown pointer -- his
companion at work or play. When the
weather was pleasant & the grass
green in the yard, I have seen him
rolling over & over on the ground with
his dog until you could scarcely
tell which was which & then standing
up they would play like boys together.
C1
B3
He was fond of riding & swimming
& on one occasion his swimming
came near costing him dearly.
It was in the Spring of 1865 &
Sheridan's raiders were sweeping
through our part of Virginia, carrying
away the remaining stock & doing
damage generally. Directed by their
parents, my brothers, Christopher & Walter,
with other neighborhood boys, had taken
all of their horses to hide from the
Union forces. They found a place
in the bend of a river some distance
from home & quite far away from
any human habitation & amid the
trees & shrubbery, thought they were
perfectly secure. So one bright morning
leaving their animals well tied, they went
for a plunge into the river -- when lo!
in the midst of their enjoyment, the
a band of raiders, led to their hiding
place by a trusted servant; dashed
in upon them & the poor fellows lost
their all & themselves too! However, I
suppose the raiders finding most of
of their captives “nothing but boys”,
& of small value, released their prison
ers & my two brothers came home
after awhile -- much to our joy &
& relief for the report spread like
wild fire & reached us at home, that
everything & everybody had been taken.
After my father's removal to Char-
lottesville & the death of my own mother
which occurred there shortly afterwards,
I saw very little of Walter except on
visits to me. These he made as often
as opportunities presented & on these
occasions we had the most delightful
reunions. He had a fine memory &
was a good talker & as far as possible,
he would live over his life in narration,
for I was as interested in everything
he did & said as anything alive
could be. How I wish now that I had
taken notes of the various accounts of
his experiences that he gave me! Some
of his stories bordered on tragedies --
the experiences of his life in New York --
among the slums & the hospitals &
his travels in the West were sometimes
attended with much danger. But he
never shirked a duty for fear of con-
sequences- He crossed deserts, evaded
rivers in the path of duty, but I could
venture the assertion that he never ceased
to be thoughtful of those about him, no
matter how great the danger, But
C1
B3
I suppose his wife has supplied
you with some of the most interesting
& thrilling incidents of his travels in
the West. Talking about him last
summer to my brother J. C. Reed, who
was at the time in Ashland, I said
that I wished so much that Walter
had kept a journal of his his life &c
& my brother replied that he had done that
very thing with a view to writing some
articles after his retirement -- when he
would have the leisure to do so, but that
in one of his moves his notebook was
lost- No doubt we could have found
many items of interest to us now that
he is gone & also much of pleasure & profit
to others. He was full of simplicity in his
estimate of himself, I think:- Seeing in the papers
various accounts of his yellow fever discovery,
I wrote, congratulating him &- In his
reply after telling me of his trip to Cuba,)
something about his experiments in which
he knew I would be greatly interested, he
says, “Of course, when one has left
wife & baby, faced death & won a victory,
it makes him happy, but it shouldn't
turn his head. He should only thank
God that his life hasn't been in vain,
& go about his business. That's what
4
I am now doing.” I could go on in
this way talking about him for
pages but am really alarmed
at the length of this letter- You
will know how to excuse me
Doctor, when I tell you that I
have lost one of the best friends
& brothers that ever lived- Since
my widowhood in 1889, Walter's
expression of sympathy with &
care for me & my children were
always touching & beautiful- His
counsels were wise & always followed
with delight & his words of cheer
were often accompanied with sub-
stantial help. He was generous
in the extreme & only when the books
are opened, I trow, will the records
of his good deeds be known. And
now again thanking you, Doctor,
for your very great kindness to
us all & with prayers for your great
success in every work of life, I am
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours Laura Reed Blincoe.
